text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at South Korea
Daily Report -- Research findings on Forensics - Forensic and Legal Medicine
are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting from Seoul, South
Korea, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Statistics on death are the
basis of a country's health, safety, and welfare policies. Emergency
physicians issue a postmortem examination certificate (PEC) for death outside
the hospital as well as a death certificate (DC) for death in the hospital."

Financial supporters for this research include Ewha Alumni Medical Research
Grant, Korean National Forensic service Grant.

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Ewha Womans
University, "This study investigated the actual conditions and criteria for
writing a DC and PEC, writing environment, and doctor's experience. The
physicians' DC and PEC writing experience and demographic data were analyzed.
The questions focused on CPR, patient's medical certificate, time and place of
death, difficulty in writing the PEC and DC, and education in certificate
writing. 229 emergency physicians were included. Physicians' opinions differed
for CPR patients in terms of time of death, location, and whether or not to
issue DC/PEC. The causes of death were also different. Further, 76.9% of the
doctors did not have enough time to write a medical certificate and about 45%
of them wrote it within 30 min; 76% had DC-related complaints, and 7.0% faced
legal problems due to the DC; 93.3% of the emergency physicians stated that a
coroner system is needed in South Korea. Emergency physicians are responsible
for writing DCs and PECs. The standards vary from physician to physician at
the time of writing. Writing DCs and PECs is also burdensome."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "In South Korea, it
is necessary to separate the DC and PEC, to develop national data management
networks, and to introduce a postmortem examination system."

For more information on this research see: Study on death certificates and
postmortem examination certificates written by Korean emergency physicians.
_Journal of Forensic and Legal Medicine_ , 2020;72():101960. (Elsevier \-
[www.elsevier.com](http://www.elsevier.com); Journal of Forensic and Legal
Medicine \- <http://www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-forensic-and-legal-
medicine/>)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting J.Y. Lim, Dept. of Emergency Medicine, Ewha Womans University,
Seoul, South Korea. Additional authors for this research include K.M. Yang and
D.H Lee.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jflm.2020.101960>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Forensic and Legal Medicine Study Findings Reported from Ewha Womans University (Study on death certificates and postmortem examination certificates written by Korean emergency physicians): Forensics - Forensic and Legal Medicine
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at South Korea Daily Report -- Research findings on Forensics - Forensic and Legal Medicine are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting from Seoul, South Korea, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “Statistics on death are the basis of a country’s health, safety, and welfare policies. Emergency physicians issue a postmortem examination certificate (PEC) for death outside the hospital as well as a death certificate (DC) for death in the hospital.”

Financial supporters for this research include Ewha Alumni Medical Research Grant, Korean National Forensic service Grant.

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Ewha Womans University, “This study investigated the actual conditions and criteria for writing a DC and PEC, writing environment, and doctor’s experience. The physicians’ DC and PEC writing experience and demographic data were analyzed. The questions focused on CPR, patient’s medical certificate, time and place of death, difficulty in writing the PEC and DC, and education in certificate writing. 229 emergency physicians were included. Physicians’ opinions differed for CPR patients in terms of time of death, location, and whether or not to issue DC/PEC. The causes of death were also different. Further, 76.9% of the doctors did not have enough time to write a medical certificate and about 45% of them wrote it within 30 min; 76% had DC-related complaints, and 7.0% faced legal problems due to the DC; 93.3% of the emergency physicians stated that a coroner system is needed in South Korea. Emergency physicians are responsible for writing DCs and PECs. The standards vary from physician to physician at the time of writing. Writing DCs and PECs is also burdensome.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “In South Korea, it is necessary to separate the DC and PEC, to develop national data management networks, and to introduce a postmortem examination system.”

For more information on this research see: Study on death certificates and postmortem examination certificates written by Korean emergency physicians. Journal of Forensic and Legal Medicine, 2020;72():101960. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Journal of Forensic and Legal Medicine - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-forensic-and-legal-medicine/)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting J.Y. Lim, Dept. of Emergency Medicine, Ewha Womans University, Seoul, South Korea. Additional authors for this research include K.M. Yang and D.H Lee.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jflm.2020.101960. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
